<fragment>
Medical sensors attached to it to track the astronaut's condition in flight were turned off to avoid shorting them out. The urine pooled in the small of his back, where it was absorbed by his undergarment.[76][77] After Shepard's flight, the space suit was modified, and by the time of Gus Grissom's Mercury-Redstone 4 suborbital flight in July, a liquid waste collection feature had been built into the suit.[78]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Shepard was awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor by President Jimmy Carter on October 1, 1978.[131] He also received the Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement in 1981;[132] the Langley Gold Medal on May 5, 1964; the John J. Montgomery Award in 1963; the Lambert trophy; the SETP Iven C. Kincheloe Award;[133] the Cabot Award; the Collier Trophy;[134] and the City of New York City Gold Medal for 1971.[92] He was awarded honorary degrees of Master of Arts from Dartmouth College in 1962, D.Sc. from Miami University in 1971, and Doctorate of Humanities from Franklin Pierce College in 1972.[92] He was inducted into the National Aviation Hall of Fame in 1977,[135] the International Space Hall of Fame in 1981,[20][136] and the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame on May 11, 1990.[122][137]




</fragment>
<fragment>
After a dramatic Atlantic Ocean recovery, Shepard observed that he "didn't really feel the flight was a success until the recovery had been successfully completed. It's not the fall that hurts; it's the sudden stop."[83] Splashdown occurred with an impact comparable to landing a jet aircraft on an aircraft carrier. A recovery helicopter arrived after a few minutes, and the capsule was lifted partly out of the water to allow Shepard to leave by the main hatch. He squeezed out of the door and into a sling hoist, and was pulled into the helicopter, which flew both the astronaut and spacecraft to the aircraft carrier USS *Lake Champlain*. The whole recovery process took just eleven minutes.[84] Shepard was celebrated as a national hero, honored with ticker-tape parades in Washington, New York and Los Angeles, and received the NASA Distinguished Service Medal from President John F. Kennedy.[85] He was also awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.[86]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![A stone memorial plaque that reads: "Love is Eternal – RADM Alan Bartlett Shepard Jr * US Navy * America's First man in Space 1998 – His loving wife Louise Brewer Shepard 1998"](image)Shepard's memorial stone in Derry, New Hampshire. His ashes were scattered at sea.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Archive footage of Shepard is used in the opening credits montage of *Star Trek: Enterprise*,as part of a sequence displaying the history of human exploration,[161] while other science fiction works have named characters in a tribute to Shepard – including both the character of Alan Tracy, in the 1960s British series *Thunderbirds*,[162] and Commander Shepard, the main protagonist of the 2007–2012 BioWare video game series *Mass Effect*.[163]


British singer-songwriter Darren Hayman's concept album *12 Astronauts* includes a song for each man who has walked on the Moon. The lyrics of *Don't Clip My Wings (Alan Shepard)*, sung in the first person, reflect on how Shepard "feared he would never fly again" after his Ménière's diagnosis.[164]


</fragment>
<fragment>
He managed to restart the engine and avoid a fatal crash.[43]


Shepard was an instructor at the Test Pilot School, and then entered the Naval War College at Newport, Rhode Island.[44] He graduated in 1957, and became an Aircraft Readiness Officer on the staff of the Commander-in-Chief, Atlantic Fleet.[45] By this time he had logged more than 3,600 hours of flying time, including 1,700 hours in jets.[46]




## NASA career[edit]


### Mercury Seven[edit]


Main article: Mercury Seven


</fragment>
<fragment>
American astronaut (1923–1998)

For other uses, see Alan Shepard (disambiguation).








</fragment>
<fragment>

Unlike Gagarin's 108-minute orbital flight in a Vostok spacecraft three times the size of *Freedom 7*,[71] Shepard stayed on a suborbital trajectory for the 15-minute flight, which reached an altitude of 101.2 nautical miles (116.5 statute miles; 187.4 kilometers), and then fell to a splashdown 263.1 nautical miles (302.8 statute miles; 487.3 kilometers) down the Atlantic Missile Range.[79] Unlike Gagarin, whose flight was strictly automatic, Shepard had some control of *Freedom 7*, spacecraft attitude in particular.[80] Shepard's launch was seen live on television by millions.[81] It was launched atop a Redstone rocket. According to Gene Kranz in his 2000 book *Failure Is Not an Option*, "When reporters asked Shepard what he thought about as he sat atop the Redstone rocket, waiting for liftoff, he had replied, 'The fact that every part of this ship was built by the lowest bidder.'"[82]




</fragment>
<fragment>

![The men wear dark suits. A Naval officer in khaki stands behind them. The White House is in the background.](image)Shepard and his wife Louise meet First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy, President John F. Kennedy and Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson at the South Portico of the White House, prior to his receiving the NASA Distinguished Service Medal on May 8, 1961.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Post Office Building.[144] Alan Shepard Park in Cocoa Beach, Florida, a beach-side park south of Cape Canaveral, is named in his honor.[145] The City of Virginia Beach renamed its convention center, with its integral geodesic dome, the *Alan B. Shepard Convention Center*. The building was later renamed the *Alan B. Shepard Civic Center*, and was razed in 1994.[146] At the time of the *Freedom 7* launch, Shepard lived in Virginia Beach.[147]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Alan Bartlett Shepard Jr. was born on November 18, 1923, at 64 Hampstead Road[1] in Derry, New Hampshire,[2] to Alan Bartlett Shepard Sr. and Pauline Renza Shepard (née Emerson).[3] He had a younger sister, Pauline, who was known as Polly.[4] The two were descendants of *Mayflower* passenger Richard Warren, [3] and were related to Scottish emigrants from Berneray in the Outer Hebrides, through the Shepard line.[5] Alan Bartlett Shepard Sr., known as Bart, worked in the Derry National Bank, owned by Shepard's grandfather. Bart joined the National Guard in 1915 and served in France with the American Expeditionary Force during World War I.[6] He remained in the National Guard between the wars, and was recalled to active duty during World War II, rising to the rank of lieutenant colonel.[7]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Shepard was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia in 1996 and died from complications of the disease in Pebble Beach, California, on July 21, 1998.[125][126][110] Shepard's widow Louise had planned to cremate his remains and scatter the ashes, but before she was able to do that, she died from a heart attack—on August 25, 1998, at 17:00, which, coincidentally, was the same time of day at which he had always phoned her when they were apart. They had been married for 53 years. Their family decided to cremate them both so their ashes were scattered, together, from a Navy helicopter over Stillwater Cove in front of their Pebble Beach home.[127][128]


On December 11, 2021, twenty-three years after his death, Shepard's daughter, Laura Shepard Churchley, also flew in space, while aboard the non-NASA Blue Origin's New Shepard 5 spaceship.[129][130]



## Awards and honors[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![Shepard, in Navy uniform short and tie, stands before a blackboard on which is stencilled "Student aviator USN – 8-19-1946 class. Above that is written in chalk: "Lt (jg) Shepard, Alan B. Jr"](image)Shepard as a student aviator in 1946
In November 1945, Shepard arrived at Naval Air Station Corpus Christi in Texas, where he commenced basic flight training on January 7, 1946.[31] He was an average student, and for a time faced being "bilged" (dropped) from flight training and reassigned to the surface navy. To make up for this, he took private lessons at a local civilian flying school—something the Navy frowned on—earning a civil pilot's license.[32] His flying skills gradually improved, and by early 1947 his instructors rated him above average. He was sent to Naval Air Station Pensacola in Florida for advanced training. His final test was six perfect landings on the carrier USS *Saipan*. The following day, he received his naval aviator wings, which his father pinned on his chest.[33]


</fragment>

<title>Edwin E. Aldrin Jr.</title>
<fragment>

| Edwin Eugene Aldrin Jr. (born January 20, 1930) is an American engineer, former astronaut, fighter pilot and Korean War veteran. As the Lunar Module Pilot on the Apollo 11 mission, he and mission commander Neil Armstrong were the first two humans to land on the Moon. Aldrin set foot on the Moon at 03:15:16 UTC on July 21, 1969 (UTC), nineteen minutes after Armstrong first touched the surface, while command module pilot Michael Collins remained in lunar orbit. A Presbyterian elder, Aldrin became the first person to hold a religious ceremony on the Moon when he privately took communion. He resigned from NASA in 1971. Aldrin is the author of multiple books documenting his space experiences and is an advocate for future space travel.


### Early life and education[edit]


Aldrin was born on January 20, 1930, in Montclair, New Jersey,[3] to Edwin Eugene Aldrin Sr. and Marion Aldrin (née Moon).[4] His father was an Army aviator during World War I; he commanded the 11th Pursuit Squadron of the American Expeditionary Force. His mother was the daughter of an Army chaplain. He had two sisters, Madeleine and Fay Ann.[4] The family moved to the Philippines in 1938 when Aldrin Sr. was transferred to Clark Field (now Clark Air Base) and remained there until 1941.[5] Aldrin attended Severn School, a private boys' school in Portsmouth, Rhode Island, but transferred to Montclair High School, Montclair, New Jersey, from which he graduated in 1947.[6] Aldrin received a Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1951, graduating third in his class.[7][8][9] He earned a Sc.D. degree in aeronautics and astronautics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1963.[10]


### Military career[edit]


In 1951, Aldrin was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the United States Air Force and served as a jet fighter pilot during the Korean War. He flew 66 combat missions in F-86 Sabres and shot down two MiG-15 aircraft. He was decorated with the Distinguished Flying Cross for his service in Korea.[11] After the war, Aldrin served as an aerial gunnery officer[12] and later as a flight commander in Germany. In 1963, he earned his Sc.D. degree and was assigned to the Gemini Target Office of the Air Force Space Systems Division.[13]


### NASA career[edit]


![Aldrin posing in his spacesuit](image)

Aldrin was selected as part of NASA's third group of astronauts in October 1963.[14] He specialized in strategies for docking and rendezvous of spacecraft in Earth and lunar orbit.[15] Aldrin served as the backup Command Module pilot for Gemini 9 and backup pilot for Gemini 12.[16] His first and only spacewalk was on the Gemini 12 mission on November 12, 1966. During this mission, he performed a 2 hour and 6 minute spacewalk, demonstrating that astronauts could function outside the spacecraft.[17]


### Apollo program[edit]


#### Apollo 11[edit]


Main article: Apollo 11


![Aldrin on the Moon during Apollo 11](image)


Aldrin was the Lunar Module Pilot of Apollo 11, the first crewed mission to land on the Moon. He followed Neil Armstrong onto the lunar surface on July 20, 1969, becoming the second person to walk on the Moon. He was on the Moon's surface for about 2 hours and 15 minutes.[18]


#### Apollo 12[edit]


Main article: Apollo 12


Aldrin was originally slated to be the Command Module Pilot of Apollo 8 but crew rotations moved him to be the Lunar Module Pilot of Apollo 11.[19] After Apollo 11, Aldrin and the crew of Apollo 12 (Commander Charles Conrad and Lunar Module Pilot Alan Bean) trained together, but Aldrin was replaced by Richard Gordon due to concerns over crew dynamics.[20]


### Post-NASA career[edit]


After leaving NASA, Aldrin became involved in various business ventures and authored several books about his space experiences, including *Return to Earth*, *Men from Earth*, and *Magnificent Desolation*.[21] He also painted scenes from the Apollo missions, often incorporating lunar dust into his artwork.[22] Aldrin has been a strong advocate for a return to the Moon and future Mars missions.[23] He developed the concept of a "Cycler" spacecraft to facilitate continuous travel between Earth and Mars.[24]


### Personal life[edit]


Aldrin has been married three times. His first marriage was to Joan Archer in 1954; they had three children before divorcing in 1974. He married Beverly Zile in 1975; they divorced in 1978.[25] Aldrin married Lois Driggs Cannon in 1988. He has no children from his second or third marriages.[26]


### Legacy[edit]


Aldrin has received numerous awards and honors, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the Congressional Gold Medal, and the NASA Distinguished Service Medal. He was inducted into the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame in 1993 and the International Space Hall of Fame in 1982.[27] The Aldrin crater on the Moon is named in his honor.[28]


### References[edit]

These are the first five astronauts to land on the moon:

1. **Neil Armstrong** - Commanded Apollo 11 and was the first human to set foot on the Moon.
2. **Buzz Aldrin** - Piloted the Lunar Module on Apollo 11 and was the second person to step on the Moon.
3. **Pete Conrad** - Commanded Apollo 12 and was the third person to walk on the Moon.
4. **Alan Bean** - Piloted the Lunar Module on Apollo 12 and was the fourth person to walk on the Moon.
5. **Alan Shepard** - Commanded Apollo 14 and was the fifth person to walk on the Moon.</s>

Aldrin is the author of multiple books documenting his space experiences and is an advocate for future space travel.


### Early life and education[edit]


Aldrin was born on January 20, 1930, in Montclair, New Jersey,[3] to Edwin Eugene Aldrin Sr. and Marion Aldrin (née Moon).[4] His father was an Army aviator during World War I; he commanded the 11th Pursuit Squadron of the American Expeditionary Force. His mother was the daughter of an Army chaplain. He had two sisters, Madeleine and Fay Ann.[4] The family moved to the Philippines in 1938 when Aldrin Sr. was transferred to Clark Field (now Clark Air Base) and remained there until 1941.[5] Aldrin attended Severn School, a private boys' school in Portsmouth, Rhode Island, but transferred to Montclair High School, Montclair, New Jersey, from which he graduated in 1947.[6] Aldrin received a Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1951, graduating third in his class.[7][8][9] He earned a Sc.D. degree in aeronautics and astronautics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1963.[10]


### Military career[edit]


In 1951, Aldrin was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the United States Air Force and served as a jet fighter pilot during the Korean War. He flew 66 combat missions in F-86 Sabres and shot down two MiG-15 aircraft. He was decorated with the Distinguished Flying Cross for his service in Korea.[11] After the war, Aldrin served as an aerial gunnery officer[12] and later as a flight commander in Germany. In 1963, he earned his Sc.D. degree and was assigned to the Gemini Target Office of the Air Force Space Systems Division.[13]


### NASA career[edit]


![Aldrin posing in his spacesuit](image)

Aldrin was selected as part of NASA's third group of astronauts in October 1963.[14] He specialized in strategies for docking and rendezvous of spacecraft in Earth and lunar orbit.[15] Aldrin served as the backup Command Module pilot for Gemini 9 and backup pilot for Gemini 12.[16] His first and only spacewalk was on the Gemini 12 mission on November 12, 1966. During this mission, he performed a 2 hour and 6 minute spacewalk, demonstrating that astronauts could function outside the spacecraft.[17]


### Apollo program[edit]


#### Apollo 11[edit]


Main article: Apollo 11


![Aldrin on the Moon during Apollo 11](image)


Aldrin was the Lunar Module Pilot of Apollo 11, the first crewed mission to land on the Moon. He followed Neil Armstrong onto the lunar surface on July 20, 1969, becoming the second person to walk on the Moon. He was on the Moon's surface for about 2 hours and 15 minutes.[18]


#### Apollo 12[edit]


Main article: Apollo 12


Aldrin was originally slated to be the Command Module Pilot of Apollo 8 but crew rotations moved him to be the Lunar Module Pilot of Apollo 11.[19] After Apollo 11, Aldrin and the crew of Apollo 12 (Commander Charles Conrad and Lunar Module Pilot Alan Bean) trained together, but Aldrin was replaced by Richard Gordon due to concerns over crew dynamics.[20]


### Post-NASA career[edit]


After leaving NASA, Aldrin became involved in various business ventures and authored several books about his space experiences, including *Return to Earth*, *Men from Earth*, and *Magnificent Desolation*.[21] He also painted scenes from the Apollo missions, often incorporating lunar dust into his artwork.[22] Aldrin has been a strong advocate for a return to the Moon and future Mars missions.[23] He developed the concept of a "Cycler" spacecraft to facilitate continuous travel between Earth and Mars.[24]


### Personal life[edit]


Aldrin has been married three times. His first marriage was to Joan Archer in 1954; they had three children before divorcing in 1974. He married Beverly Zile in 1975; they divorced in 1978.[25] Aldrin married Lois Driggs Cannon in 1988. He has no children from his second or third marriages.[26]


### Legacy[edit]


Aldrin has received numerous awards and honors, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the Congressional Gold Medal, and the NASA Distinguished Service Medal. He was inducted into the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame in 1993 and the International Space Hall of Fame in 1982.[27] The Aldrin crater on the Moon is named in his honor.[28]

| Edwin Eugene Aldrin Jr. (born January 20, 1930) is an American engineer, former astronaut, fighter pilot and Korean War veteran. As the Lunar Module Pilot on the Apollo 11 mission, he and mission commander Neil Armstrong were the first two humans to land on the Moon. Aldrin set foot on the Moon at 03:15:16 UTC on July 21, 1969 (UTC), nineteen minutes after Armstrong first touched the surface, while command module pilot Michael Collins remained in lunar orbit. A Presbyterian elder, Aldrin became the first person to hold a religious ceremony on the Moon when he privately took communion. He resigned from NASA in 1971. Aldrin is the author of multiple books documenting his space experiences and is an advocate for future space travel.

These are the birth states of the first five astronauts to land on the moon:

2. **Buzz Aldrin** - Born in Montclair, New Jersey
3. **Pete Conrad** - Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
4. **Alan Bean** - Born in Wheeler, Texas
5. **Alan Shepard** - Born in Derry, New Hampshire
